724686f-b.title: Manhattan: West Street - Houston Street (West)
724686f-b.text:
(1)
Vest Street, east side, north from No. 34t, north of West
Houston Street (formerly Hammersly Street), opposite Pier
39, North River.
October 25, 1927.
L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, four years later, after the buildings north to
Clarkson Street have been cleared away for the site of the
New York Central \& Hudson River Railroad's new St. John's
Park Freight Terminal.
Both of these pictures show the boys on horseback who rode
ahead of trains on Tenth Avenue and Y.est Street before
the building of the elevated roadbed along the west side
of Washington Street (q.v.).
January 18, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724686f-b.folder: West Street & Houston Street (West), Manhattan, NY

724685f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Houston Street (West)
724685f-a.text:
Whest Street, east side, from West Houston Street (forrerly Hammiersley
Street), oppoaite Pier 39, North River, to Charlton Street,
opposite Pier 37. Demolition of buildings, for the site of
the new St. John's Park Terminal, is going on.
September 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724685f-a.folder: West Street & Houston Street (West), Manhattan, NY

724690f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Houston Street (West)
724690f-a.text:
West Street, east side, from West Houston Street (formerly
Hammersley Street), opposite Pier 39, North River, to Leroy
Street, opposite Pier 41. The lunch room on the corner at
the right was supposed to have been in the hands of one
family for a hundred years.
Hammersley Street (it was absorbed in 1858 by Houston Street,
and lost its own name) was, prior to the redistricting of
1917, the south boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was
roughly identical with 'Greenwich Village.''
October 25, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, a year and a half later, and including one or two
buildings north of Leroy Street.
March 6, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3) wat Street,East Side from Leroy and Clarkson Streets,lookirg
Sonth. At the South Ec t corner of Leroy Street is the new depot
of the :onarch Freight 5yetem.
Meg 7th,T3
'.L.Sperr,

724688f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Houston Street (West)
724688f-a.text:
Doherty's Hotel, 342 West Street at the S. E. corner of West Houston
Street (formerly Hammersley Street), opposite Pier 39, North
River. adjoining the hotel used to be the Church of the Holy
Comforter on the Houston Street side, and the Seamen's Church
Institute at 341-340 West Street. The hotel itself will have
to go in 1930.
October 25, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724688f-a.folder: West Street & Houston Street (West), Manhattan, NY

724529f-b.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (West - West Street
724529f-b.text:
(1)
350 to 342 West Houston Street, western section (formerly
Hammersley Street), at and adjoining the north corner of West
Street.
May 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.:
.
(2)
342 to 350 West Houston Street, the same scene viewed from the
east, two years later. Everything in this westermost block
of West Houston Sfreet will be demolished in 1930, and the
street later closed.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

724691f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Houston Street (West)
724691f-a.text:
West Street, east side, from No. 346, north of West Houston Street
(Fier 39, North River), to No. 3o5, north of Leroy Street (Pier 41).
October 25, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

724689f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Houston Street (West)
724689f-a.text:
340, 341 West Street, adjoining the S.E. corner of Houston Street
(opposite Pier 39, North River). This is part of the site of
the future new St. John's Park Freight Terminal.
March 6, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

West Street at the N.E. corner of West Houston Street (formerly
Hammersly Street), opposite Pier 39, North River.
June 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

724532f-b.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (West - West Street
724532f-b.text:
(1)
Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), south side, from
west Street towards Greenwich Street. The Church of the Holy Comforter
used to stand at No. 345-341, where the billboards now hide the vacant
1ot; it was taken down less than eight years before the date of
this picture.
June 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, a view all the way to Greenwich Street, three months
later after the West to Washington Street block has been cleared,
showing the east side of Washington Street, and, in the background,
the new Standard Statistics Building under construction on the west
aide of Hudson Street, from King to Charlton Streets.
September 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724532f-b.folder: Houston Street (West & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724532f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (West - West Street
724532f-a.text:
(1)

724532f-a.folder: Houston Street (West & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724531f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (West - West Street
724531f-a.text:
Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), east from and in-
cluding West Street. Hammersley Street was one of the group of
parallel east-west streets laid out in the Trinity Church Farm, and
hmet the western end of the original Houston Street just east across
the line between the Trinity Farm and the West Bayard Farm, at the
aouthern end of Bedford Street (1.v.).
In 1858 this street lost its own name and was absorbed by Houston
Street. At that time, and thereafter till the redistricting of 1917,
it served as the southern boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was
roughly identical with Greenwich Village.
In 1930 these buildings at and east of West Street will be de-
molished for the site of the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal
(see West Street). Houston Street, from West to Washington Streets,
will be permanently closed and incorporated with the site of the
freight station.
March 6, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724531f-a.folder: Houston Street (West & West Street, Manhattan, NY
